questions.question: Question 1: Glucocorticoids act on which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Glucocorticoids act on the intracellular cytoplasmic receptors. They diffuse into cytosol and bind to the cytoplasmic receptors and influence nuclear changes by 
activation of the receptor. 626 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 2: Glucocorticoids do not have permissive action on which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Glucocorticoids do not have permissive action on bradykinin. They inhibit inflammatory 
mediators such as histamine, bradykinin, and eicosanoids. Glucocorticoids possess permissive action on the vasoconstrictor effect of angiotensin and 
lipolytic action of adrenaline and noradrenaline. In the absence of glucocorticoids, these 
hormones have low activity but the presence enhances their activity several folds.

questions.question:
Question 3: A pregnant woman diagnosed with Cushing's syndrome does not want surgery and requests 
medical treatment. Which of the following drugs can be recommended?
questions.explanation:
Metyrapone can be recommended as it is approved in the treatment of pregnant women with 
Cushing's syndrome. It inhibits the synthesis of cortisol by inhibiting steroid 11 -hydroxylase 
reversibly. Cushing’s syndrome (CS) is a manifestation of symptoms that are precipitated by excessive 
cortisol production. Transsphenoidal surgery, radiation, and pharmacotherapy constitute the 
standard treatment for tumor-related causes of CS (e.g. pituitary adenoma). The three main pharmacological approaches are: • Cortisol synthesis inhibitors: Ketoconazole, metyrapone, mitotane, etomidate, 
aminoglutethimide • ACTH secretion inhibitors: Cyproheptadine, pasireotide, octreotide, cabergoline • Glucocorticoid receptor antagonist: Mifepristone Note: Metyrapone is also used to test the hypothalamic-pituitary feedback pathway in the 
diagnosis of Cushing syndrome.

questions.question:
Question 4: The enzyme A in the following image corresponds to? 620 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
"A" here corresponds to 11-beta-HSD2 (11-Hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase2). It converts active 
cortisol to inactive cortisone. Cortisol is active and can bind to both glucocorticoids and mineralocorticoid receptors whereas 
cortisone is inactive and does not bind to either. The selective inactivation of cortisol is required 
in certain sites such as the distal nephron so that the specific autoregulatory responses to 
aldosterone can be achieved. Therefore, cortisol (active) is metabolized to cortisone (inactive) by 11-beta-HSD2 in the kidney, so 
as to protect renal mineralocorticoid receptors from cortisol binding. Some tissues, like the liver, 
can convert inactive cortisone back to active cortisol through an enzyme called 11-beta-HSD1 ("B" 
in the image). This completes the “cortisone–cortisol shuttle” because the kidney can inactivate 
cortisol where it is not needed and the liver can reactivate it afterward. 627 
Sold by @itachibot However, when circulating cortisol levels are very high, as in severe Cushing syndrome, they can 
overwhelm this protective mechanism, allowing cortisol to bind to and activate the 
mineralocorticoid receptor. This leads to volume expansion, hypertension, and hypokalemia often 
observed in hypercortisolism. A mutation of 11-beta-HSD2 also causes a similar clinical picture 
and is the reason for the syndrome of apparent mineralocorticoid excess. 17-Hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase and 3-Hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase are involved in the 
metabolism of sex steroids.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following is a prodrug?
questions.explanation:
Prednisone is a prodrug. It is a synthetic glucocorticoid that is biologically inert until converted via hepatic 
metabolism (11-beta HSD1) to the active component, prednisolone.

Question 6: A patient with moderate COVID-1‘ was started on a long-acting glucocorticoid. Which of the 
following drugs could it be?
questions.explanation: Dexamethasone is the longest acting glucocorticoid. Its t1/2 is >36 hours.

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following is not a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist?
questions.explanation:
Metyrapone is not a mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist. It is a selective inhibitor of 11-hydroxylase and thereby reduces cortisol and corticosterone 
synthesis. Options A and B - Spironolactone and eplerenone are aldosterone antagonist that is used in 
hypertension and chronic CHF for reversing the effects of aldosterone Option C - Drospirenone is a 4th generation progestin used as an oral contraceptive having 
mineralocorticoid antagonist action

questions.question:
Question 9: A woman diagnosed with Sheehan's syndrome is planned for the initiation of hormone 
replacement. Glucocorticoids should be administered prior to thyroxine supplementation due 
to what concern?

options.c: Decrease in the metabolism of glucocorticoids

questions.explanation:
Glucocorticoids are administered before initiating treatment with thyroid hormones as 
administration of thyroxine can precipitate acute adrenal insufficiency. In the case of combined adrenal insufficiency and hypothyroidism, as in panhypopituitarism (due 
to surgery or Sheehan's syndrome), adrenal insufficiency is generally treated first. This is because 
giving thyroxine first can enhance cortisol clearance and precipitate an adrenal crisis. Also, 
levothyroxine increases the basal metabolic rate (BMR) leading to an increased requirement of 
cortisol, which if not met can also precipitate an adrenal crisis.

questions.question:
Question 10: A pregnant woman came for routine antenatal screening. During prenatal testing, the fetus 
was suspected to have congenital adrenal hyperplasia. What is the drug of choice for treating 
the fetus in-utero?
questions.explanation:
The drug of choice for treating the fetus in-utero when suspected of having congenital adrenal 
hyperplasia is dexamethasone. 629 
Sold by @itachibot Dexamethasone readily crosses the placenta and suppresses the secretion of steroids and 
androgens by fetal adrenal glands. If started by 6 weeks of gestation, it reduces the virilization of 
external genitalia in affected females. Chorionic villus biopsy is then performed to determine the sex and the genotype of the fetus and 
therapy is only continued if the fetus is an affected female. This is not widely accepted currently due to insufficient data on long-term risks especially in 
unaffected females and males who derive no benefit from the treatment.

questions.question:
Question 11: A patient is started on hormone replacement for chronic adrenal insufficiency. What is the 
replacement dose of hydrocortisone that has to be given (in mg/day)?
questions.explanation:
The replacement dose of hydrocortisone for chronic adrenal insufficiency is 20 mg/day. The treatment of chronic adrenal insufficiency (not in crisis) requires glucocorticoid replacement 
at a dose that replaces the physiologic daily cortisol production. This is achieved by administering 
an oral replacement dose of 15-25mg Hydrocortisone. A midpoint dose of 20mg is given in 2-3 divided doses: 10mg + 5mg + 5mg. A higher morning dose is given at 8:30 am (usually 1/2 to 2/3 of the total dose). The next dose is 
given at 1:30 pm and in the evening (4:30-5:00 pm). This is to follow the normal circadian 
rhythm.

questions.question:
Question 12: A pregnant woman at 33 weeks of gestation presents to your antenatal clinic with preterm 
labour. Which corticosteroid will you administer for stimulation of fetal lung maturation?
questions.explanation:
Betamethasone is indicated for the stimulation of fetal lung maturation in preterm labor. As compared to cortisol, betamethasone binds to maternal proteins less and has less placental 
metabolism. This allows increased transfer to the fetus. Additionally, infants exposed to 
betamethasone are less likely to require postnatal resuscitation. 2 doses of 12 mg each are 
administered 18-24 hours apart when the delivery is anticipated before 34 weeks of gestation. Dexamethasone is another long-acting glucocorticoid that can be given. It has benefits such as less 
risk of intraventricular hemorrhage and a shorter length of stay in the NICU.

questions.question:
Question 13: A patient with chronic adrenal insufficiency is on long term corticosteroid therapy. Which of 
the following side effects is he unlikely to experience?
questions.explanation:
Corticosteroid therapy does not cause muscular hypertrophy and the patient is unlikely to 
experience it as a side effect. Excess glucocorticoid activity results in muscle wasting and myopathy while excess 
mineralocorticoid activity results in hypokalemia and causes muscle weakness. Options B and C: Peptic ulceration and psychosis are known adverse effects of corticosteroids. Option D: Glucocorticoids with some mineralocorticoid activity will result in sodium and water 
retention and may cause hypertension. 630 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 14: You are planning to add oral steroids to manage a case of severe asthma. Presence of which of 
the following comorbidities is not a relative contraindication for starting the medication?
questions.explanation:
Eczematous skin diseases are not a contraindication for the use of oral corticosteroids. In fact, 
they are highly effective and are indicated in this condition. All the contraindications to steroids are relative because of the life-saving nature of steroids. Risk-benefit should be assessed cautiously when initiating steroids in the following conditions: • Diabetes mellitus • Hypertension • Peptic ulcer • Viral and fungal infections • Tuberculosis and other infections • Osteoporosis • Herpes simplex keratitis • Epilepsy • CHF • Renal failure

questions.question:
Question 15: A 54-year-old woman is being evaluated for chronic back pain. She mentions that she had 
been on corticosteroids for asthma since childhood. Which of the following actions of the 
drug would not cause her condition?
questions.explanation:
Chronic back pain following long term corticosteroid therapy is suggestive of 
osteoporosis. Glucocorticoids do not inhibit of the action of osteoclasts. It causes stimulation of osteoclasts and increases bone resorption. Mechanism of glucocorticoids induced osteoporosis: • Inhibition of gonadal steroidal hormones • Reduced gastrointestinal absorption of calcium • Secondary effect of decreased calcium absorption: increased parathyroid hormone leading to 
further resorption • Suppressive action on osteoblasts • Stimulation of osteoclasts

questions.question: Question 16: Osteonecrosis following glucocorticoid therapy is most commonly associated with which site?
questions.explanation:
The femoral head is the most frequently affected site by osteonecrosis due to glucocorticoid 
therapy. 631 
Sold by @itachibot The earliest symptoms are joint pain and stiffness. When patients on steroid therapy develop hip, 
shoulder or knee pain, osteonecrosis must be considered and ruled out. Options B and D - It can also affect the distal femur and humeral head Option C - Osteonecrosis of the jaw is associated with the use of bisphosphonates

questions.question:
Question 17: A patient with Cushing’s syndrome has very high levels of ACTH. Which of the following is a 
CRH preparation that can be used to determine if it is a pituitary source or an ectopic source?
questions.explanation:
Corticorelin is a corticotrophin-releasing hormone (CRH) preparation used in CRH stimulation 
test which helps to differentiate between a pituitary source and an ectopic source for 
ACTH-dependent hypercortisolism. Pituitary tumors tend to be sensitive to CRH stimulation and responds with a rise in cortisol while 
ectopic tumors do not usually respond. Ectopic sources of ACTH include carcinoid, medullary 
thyroid carcinoma, and pheochromocytoma. It can also be used to test the HPA axis. Option A - Gonadorelin is a recombinant GnRH. Option C - Ganirelix is a GnRH antagonist. Option D - Cosyntropin is a synthetic preparation of ACTH.

questions.question:
Question 18: 624 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is a steroid receptor antagonist that can be given to a patient with 
Cushing’s syndrome due to ectopic ACTH?
questions.explanation:
Mifepristone is a steroid receptor antagonist that can be used in Cushing’s syndrome. It is used in Cushing’s syndrome especially in inoperable cases with ectopic ACTH secretion or 
adrenal carcinoma. Options A, B, and D - Ketoconazole, metyrapone, and aminoglutethimide reduce steroid synthesis 
by enzyme inhibition.

questions.question:
Question 19: Which of the following intravenous anaesthetics can be used for acute control of 
hypercortisolism?
questions.explanation:
The intravenous anesthetic that can be used for acute control of hypercortisolism is etomidate. Etomidate at sub-hypnotic doses inhibits cortisol secretion by selectively inhibiting 
11-beta-hydroxylase activity. It is used off-label to treat hypercortisolism when rapid control is needed and the patient is not 
able to take oral medication.

questions.explanation:
632

Question 21: Which of the following antifungal drugs can be used in the treatment of a patient with 
Cushing syndrome?

options.a: Ca2+ sensing receptor is a voltage gated ion channel

questions.explanation:
Ketoconazole can be used in the treatment of Cushing syndrome for symptomatic control. It is a non-selective inhibitor of adrenal and gonadal steroid synthesis. These actions are more 
apparent at higher doses than those used for fungal infections. 633
